topics.body:
I am writing an opinion piece on GMO safety at school. I am thinking of distributing it around the school as a booklet.

Does anyone have any advice on what I could write about?
topics.author: 50b70eeb7f123b1a02000097

topics.body:
"@twistedmetalero":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/539938ed63687217ff280200#post_539938ed63687217ff280200

Originally by Black Flag.

"@gasmaskangel":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/5399395163687216fb3a0200#post_5399395163687216fb3a0200


believe it or not, lil wayne used to be good, back in 2007 his mixtape da drought 3 was rather interesting (some say it was his best work), but after that it was nothing but downhill

that ice t cover was cool.

topics.body:
"@Randomosaur":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/53993a3e6368725282580100#post_53993a3e6368725282580100
I'd recommend emphasizing the benefits of GMO food, particularly the humanitarian benefits. Address safety concerns and be honest about the various shady shit that has gone down. Make sure you have actual data to combat the scaremongering.
topics.author: 4f41ee04945b701c41002af7

topics.body:
"@Randomosaur":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/53993b1c6368721830c90200#post_53993b1c6368721830c90200
You do realize that you can edit your posts right?
topics.author: 5062d6f17f123b3e16001184

topics.body:
"@gasmaskangel":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/53993bbc636872428b000000#post_53993bbc636872428b000000
I have listed seven independently funded studies on GMO safety, and wrote down the basics of what the studies did and what they found. 

As for "shady shit", I know Monsanto has some pretty strict rules on reusing their seeds. Anything else they have done that sounds dodgy?

I will probably write a section on Golden Rice.

I want my piece to be science-based, but I don't want it to look like a Nazi propaganda piece either.
topics.author: 50b70eeb7f123b1a02000097

topics.body:
"@Randomosaur":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/53993e1e6368724253ad0000#post_53993e1e6368724253ad0000
Possibly something on how the modern GMO processes are essentially an extension on how we've been breeding plants and animals for centuries? Maybe a brief run down of basic genetics and how they're moved around in the laboratory.

topics.body:
"@trashboat":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/53993fd16368720a1d010000#post_53993fd16368720a1d010000
This is not a debate. I'm just looking for advice on how I could make a good and balanced piece of writing.

I'm definitely going to cite these two cases of horizontal gene transfer in nature:

"http://phenomena.nationalgeographic.com/2013/01/01/how-a-quarter-of-the-cow-genome-came-from-snakes/":http://phenomena.nationalgeographic.com/2013/01/01/how-a-quarter-of-the-cow-genome-came-from-snakes/
"http://www.nytimes.com/2014/04/17/science/plants-that-practice-genetic-engineering.html?hpw&rref=science&_r=2":http://www.nytimes.com/2014/04/17/science/plants-that-practice-genetic-engineering.html?hpw&rref=science&_r=2

Both of these occurred in nature, and neither of these caused a big ecological collapse, nor did they mess up the ecosystem.
topics.author: 50b70eeb7f123b1a02000097
